From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Mar 11 17:39:26 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (bonefish)
Date: Wed, 11 Mar 2009 16:39:26 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3308: Possible floating point failures in
 IEEE 754 tests
In-Reply-To: <042.c678ed2b992fdb50f53485f9b7f8d349@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.c678ed2b992fdb50f53485f9b7f8d349@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.c73dfcb655f49a4922c84a82706ba6ac@haiku-os.org>

#3308: Possible floating point failures in IEEE 754 tests
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  scottmc            |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  critical           |   Milestone:  R1/alpha1     
Component:  System/libroot.so  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------

Comment(by bonefish):

 Replying to [comment:10 oco]:
 > Maybe writing only 10 bytes is OK because it is the maximum size of FPU
 registers in x86. But is it OK to keep 2 bytes in case the memory was not
 initialized ? At least, if i am not wrong, the sign should be in the last
 one, no ?

 No idea. gcc 4.3.1 in Linux also says sizeof(long double) == 12, so I
 guess that much is correctly at least.

 long double support in our gcc 2.95.3 is known to be broken. From what
 I've heard it is OK in the same gcc version for other platforms, so this
 is supposedly a gcc configuration problem. I guess looking in gcc's
 documentation for configuration defines that influence long double
 behavior and comparing the configurations for other platforms with ours
 would be a good start to track the problem down.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3308#comment:11>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Mar 11 18:14:56 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmadia)
Date: Wed, 11 Mar 2009 17:14:56 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3546: Information regarding DriveSetup
	implementation
Message-ID: <041.cc70e49043b7139ffd72d7326723151d@haiku-os.org>

#3546: Information regarding DriveSetup implementation
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia                   |       Owner:  stippi
     Type:  enhancement              |      Status:  new   
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1    
Component:  Applications/DriveSetup  |     Version:        
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  All   
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 This ticket is to help consolidate details of implementing missing
 features in DriveSetup.

 [http://www.freelists.org/post/haiku-development/Partitioning-support-in-
 Alpha1 Partitioning support in Alpha/1] from [haiku-development]
 This entire thread should be read.

 [http://www.freelists.org/post/haiku-development/boot-manager-error,9 boot
 manager error] from [haiku-development]
 > No you didn't miss anything, Create and Delete and still showing as (not
 > implemented).

 Correct. It's not only DriveSetup, the problem is the unfinished disk
 device add-ons (with regard to write support). There are two add-ons, one
 for "Intel Partition Map", which handles (the four) primary partitions and
 "Intel Extended Partition", which handles "logical partitions" when one of
 the primary is an extended partition. The later is unfinished and the
 former could use some work as well. Initially, I was on the wrong track
 with regards to representing the options in DriveSetup. For example, there
 is no such thing as a "logical partition" in the on disk structures. There
 is multiple conventions for partition layout, different operating systems
 support different stuff, a great potential for screw ups here. So I didn't
 explore this any further for the time being, I have a pile of uncommited
 changes that I did before realizing there are no "logical partitions" (as
 a
 type). When a partition is created, it is actually created with the type
 of
 the file system, I thought one could create a partition and then decide on
 the file system, wrong. Need to get back to that sometimes...


 [http://www.freelists.org/post/haiku/GSoC-2009-some-more-TODO-requesting-
 help,24 misc thread] from [haiku]:
 I've looked into this before and some of the stuff which is missing in the
 kernel is really not obvious. I tried to start with a clean drive, but
 there is already a problem, the Haiku kernel does not assign a disk system
 (Intel Partition Map?, EFI GUID?, Amiga Disk System?) to that. But most
 operations, like even getting the list of available disk systems in a user
 program, require a valid object hierarchy in the kernel. Personally, I
 don't regard it as critical for Alpha1 but it would be nice if someone
 finally tackled this for real. It must be done sometimes... :-) Maybe Ingo
 and I could both mentor this.

 Another reply, from [http://www.freelists.org/post/haiku/GSoC-2009-some-
 more-TODO-requesting-help,24 the same thread] from [haiku]
 > How do you initialise a partition as BFS?
 The disk system has to be already established. Ie it needs to be Intel
 Partition Map, and the partition needs to exist. At least DriveSetup
 allows you to initializes whole drives, but then there is no disk system.
 The file system in this case starts at offset 0. No MBR or anything like
 that. Why initializing doesn't work in your particular case, I do not
 know.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3546>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 struct bfs_inode;

 struct small_data {
         uint32          type;
         uint16          name_size;
         uint16          data_size;
         char            name[0];        // name_size long, followed by
 data

         uint32 Type() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(type); }
         uint16 NameSize() const { return
 BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT16(name_size); }
         uint16 DataSize() const { return
 BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT16(data_size); }

         inline char             *Name() const;
         inline uint8    *Data() const;
         inline uint32   Size() const;
         inline small_data *Next() const;
         inline bool             IsLast(const bfs_inode *inode) const;
 } _PACKED;

 // the file name is part of the small_data structure
 #define FILE_NAME_TYPE                  'CSTR'
 #define FILE_NAME_NAME                  0x13
 #define FILE_NAME_NAME_LENGTH   1


 //**************************************

 class Volume;

 #define SHORT_SYMLINK_NAME_LENGTH       144 // length incl. terminating
 '\0'

 struct bfs_inode {
         int32           magic1;
         inode_addr      inode_num;
         int32           uid;
         int32           gid;
         int32           mode;                           // see sys/stat.h
         int32           flags;
         bigtime_t       create_time;
         bigtime_t       last_modified_time;
         inode_addr      parent;
         inode_addr      attributes;
         uint32          type;                           // attribute type

         int32           inode_size;
         uint32          etc;                            // a pointer to
 the Inode object during construction

         union {
                 data_stream             data;
                 char
 short_symlink[SHORT_SYMLINK_NAME_LENGTH];
         };
         int32           pad[4];

         small_data      small_data_start[0];

         int32 Magic1() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(magic1); }
         int32 UserID() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(uid); }
         int32 GroupID() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(gid); }
         int32 Mode() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(mode); }
         int32 Flags() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(flags); }
         int32 Type() const { return BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(type); }
         int32 InodeSize() const { return
 BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT32(inode_size); }
         bigtime_t LastModifiedTime() const { return
 BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT64(last_modified_time); }
         bigtime_t CreateTime() const { return
 BFS_ENDIAN_TO_HOST_INT64(create_time); }
         small_data *SmallDataStart() { return small_data_start; }

         status_t InitCheck(Volume *volume);
                 // defined in Inode.cpp
 } _PACKED;

 ...

#3548: Single Window Nav : opt+alt+down : broken
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia                |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Tracker  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                        |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                        |  
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 When comparing keyboard navigation between Single and Multiple window
 navigation,  opt (winkey)+alt+down functions as expected in multiple
 window navigation, yet is functionless in single window mode.

 r29476

 Single window:
 alt+up: navigate to parent
 alt+down: navigate to selected folder
 opt+alt+up: new window of parent
 opt+alt+down: nada ,

 Multi-window:
 alt+up: new window of parent
 alt+down: new window of selected folder
 opt+alt+up: navigate to parent
 opt+alt+down: navigate to selected folder

#3547: cc fails when compiling bfs_disk_system.cpp
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Phoenix137        |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  File Systems/BFS  |     Version:  R1 development

 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------

Comment(by monni):

 I would say this is not a bug. It is known fact that Haiku doesn't support
 64-bit compilers. 32-bit "subsystem" just changes the identification
 string returned by "uname", but doesn't actually change the compiler.
 Compiler command line and output suggest it is still using 64-bit
 compiler.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 12 07:50:47 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmadia)

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3549: Another Disks-Icon related issue in

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 12 09:39:03 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (PieterPanman)
Date: Thu, 12 Mar 2009 08:39:03 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3546: Information regarding DriveSetup
	implementation
In-Reply-To: <041.cc70e49043b7139ffd72d7326723151d@haiku-os.org>
References: <041.cc70e49043b7139ffd72d7326723151d@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <050.9c96ef754ce23dcff34971cf0024b836@haiku-os.org>

#3546: Information regarding DriveSetup implementation
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia                   |       Owner:  stippi
     Type:  enhancement              |      Status:  new   
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1    
Component:  Applications/DriveSetup  |     Version:        
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  All   
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
Changes (by PieterPanman):

 * cc: pieter@? (added)


Comment:

 Is it an idea to use [http://www.gnu.org/software/parted/index.shtml
 libparted] and [http://www.linux-ntfs.org/doku.php?id=ntfsprogs
 ntfsprogs]/[http://www.linux-ntfs.org/doku.php?id=libntfs libntfs] as the
 backend for file system manipulations? It is well maintained and heavily
 tested. You even get NTFS resize functionality with libntfs. I know I've
 resized several NTFS volumes with it, successfully.
 I guess there are two options:

 1) Make the unfinished disk device add-ons use libparted and libntfs, and
 let drivesetup use the disk device add-ons. (preferred I guess)

 2) Let drivesetup be like GParted, which directly uses libparted and
 libntfs. (not really in line of what Haiku is doing now)

 I'm not quite sure about licensing issues, but if you just use the
 library, you don't have to GPL your own code, right?

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3546#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Component:  Applications/DriveSetup  |     Version:        
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  All

-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------

Comment(by PieterPanman):

 Ah, shoot, I forgot about that, thanks for the refresher:
 http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#IfLibraryIsGPL

 Can we write a wrapper around it to make it a standalone program/service,
 publish that as GPL, and connect with the wrapper through
 messages/ports/whatever?
 It would be such a shame to have to write all this functionality over
 again.

 In http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#GPLInProprietarySystem it
 states:
 "However, in many cases you can distribute the GPL-covered software
 alongside your proprietary system. To do this validly, you must make sure
 that the free and non-free programs communicate at arms length, that they
 are not combined in a way that would make them effectively a single
 program."

--

Comment(by hey68you):

 If I'm not mistaken I think we do need to invalidate the container
 BTabView (i.e. it's not a bug). Quoting the BeBook:

 {{{
 SetLabel()
 Can be augmented to take notice when the tab's label is changed. You
 should always call the inherited version of the function before your
 implementation returns.
 }}}

 The existing Terminal code doesn't have an augmented version of the
 BTab::SetLabel() method which I assume would do the invalidating of the
 BTabview container view upon noticing a new text for the label.

 So is it ok that I'm calling fTabView->Invalidate() on my own straight
 after modifying the label text using the un-augmented BTab::SetLabel()
 method ???

 Blocking:                    |

Comment(by monni):

 As far as I know it should say "-m32" when it is compiling 32-bit code.
 configure script should add that automatically if your environment is
 recognized as 64-bit. You can also force configure to always add that flag
 by adding --use-32bit to configure command line.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 12 13:58:03 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Adek336)
Date: Thu, 12 Mar 2009 12:58:03 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3550: [mmap] Freezes when maping lots of
	memory
Message-ID: <042.88d89a4b9c13d5f9eae9616a7f2290bc@haiku-os.org>

#3550: [mmap] Freezes when maping lots of memory
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336        |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Test program:
 {{{
 #include <stdio.h>
 #include <stdlib.h>
 #include <string.h>
 #include <sys/mman.h>

 int main()
 {
         char name[1024];
         strcpy(name, "/tmp/adipeXXXXXX");
         int fd = mkstemp(name);
         if (fd == -1)
         {
                 perror("mkstemp");
                 exit(1);
         }

         void *v;

         int i;
         for (i = 0; i < 4000000; i++)
         {
                 v = mmap(NULL, 1000* getpagesize(), PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE,
 MAP_SHARED, fd, 0);
                 fprintf(stderr, "i = %d\n", i);
                 if (v == (caddr_t) -1)
                 {
                         perror("mmap");
                         exit(1);
                 }
         }


         close(fd);
         return 0;
 }

 }}}

 On Haiku: the program freezes after i = 224, can't ctrl-c it, can't open
 the context menu when clicking on the cpu meter in Deskbar, the app
 doesn't close when Terminal is closed, the Shutdown dialog freezes, cpu
 meter in Deskbar shows 100%.

 For comparison, on Linux: after some iterations, "mmap: Cannot allocate
 memory"

 Tested under vmware, r29445, hybrid build, 524 MiB memory in the guest
 machine.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3550>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------

Comment(by monni):

 Replying to [comment:5 mmadia]:
 > Replying to [comment:4 monni]:
 > >  You can also force configure to always add that flag by adding --use-
 32bit to configure command line.
 >
 > That shouldn't be necessary with #3391

 I know... I only listed it as "last resort" if auto-detecting fails for
 any reason. I'm really not familiar on how much "linux32" masquerades the
 system in each different distribution and as the flag still does exist,
 there is likely reason for it.

#3503: gcc-4.3.3-haiku-090129 does not include 3rdparty in its include search list
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  titer         |       Owner:  mmlr          
      Type:  bug           |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1 development
Resolution:  fixed         |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  All           |    Blocking:                
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by andreasf):

 Please note that we have conflicting {{{iconv.h}}} files in {{{3rdparty}}}
 and {{{posix}}}. The latter corresponds to the original implementation in
 {{{libtextencoding.so}}}, while the former corresponds to
 {{{libiconv.so}}}.

 With this search path, the one in {{{posix}}} is always hidden.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3503#comment:5>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Component:  Applications/Command Line Tools  |     Version:  R1 development

 src/bin/diffutils/config.h:
 {{{
    1259 /* Define to 1 if strerror_r returns char *. */
    1260 #define STRERROR_R_CHAR_P 1

 #undef STRERROR_R_CHAR_P

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #2641: [nvidia] Video problems
In-Reply-To: <041.5e66e5d31b4e574ab0cd37fd18661280@haiku-os.org>
References: <041.5e66e5d31b4e574ab0cd37fd18661280@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <050.59fb974c90b7dada062c05221c99e5a1@haiku-os.org>

#2641: [nvidia] Video problems
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  VinDuv                   |       Owner:  rudolfc       
     Type:  bug                      |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/Graphics/nVidia  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------

Comment(by VinDuv):

 Hi Rudolf,

 The internal display was used when I activated logging. I made some other
 tests with and without the CRT connected (see the attached log).[[BR]]
 The driver does not work in BeOS R5 either (same behavior)[[BR]]
 But the good news is that the driver is at least partially working !

 What I have done :[[BR]]
 1. Set switchhead to true, reboot with the external CRT => image OK (on
 external)[[BR]]
 2. Reboot => still OK[[BR]]
 3. Change resolution to the highest provided, 1400x1050 (it is not a
 standard resolution for the external screen, but it is the native
 resolution of the internal one - I guess this is a side effect of
 switchhead) => OK[[BR]]
 4. Reboot => Not OK, freeze after the rocket icon, with the internal, the
 external or both screens enabled (even KDL wasn't showing)[[BR]]
 5. Reboot with switchhead disabled => OK on internal ![[BR]]
 6. Changing resolution => Not OK (same behavior as before)

 So it seems that only the native resolution works properly on the internal
 screen.

--

#3308: Possible floating point failures in IEEE 754 tests
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  scottmc            |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  critical           |   Milestone:  R1/alpha1     
Component:  System/libroot.so  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------

Comment(by oco):

 Oh ! I was wrong about the sign. The long double type has a size of 12
 bytes but it contains a 10 bytes floating point value (the x87 native
 format). 2 padding bytes are added to complete the value.

 Here is post about this :

  - http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.linux.c-programming/2780/focus=2782

 I will take a look at configuration on other platforms. But i may also try
 to track down the difference beetween fpc and gcc. This could help me find
 what kind of configuration i should search for in gcc.

--

Message-ID: <049.1995d5b5d6960933ee709ce4a3cbb455@haiku-os.org>

#2010: (Missing symbol: ) error message don't show any actual missing symbols.
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
  Reporter:  diver                 |       Owner:  axeld         
      Type:  bug                   |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  Applications/Tracker  |     Version:  R1 development

  Platform:  All                   |    Blocking:

  * status:  new => closed
  * resolution:  => fixed


Comment:

 The runtime_loader didn't provide the missing symbol name (fixed in
 r29515) and the Tracker used an outdated function signature and failed to
 actually get the error details for both missing symbols and missing
 libraries (fixed in r29516).

 copied, not the file count, since in terms of copy time that's what

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 17:08:42 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (BeOSR)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 16:08:42 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3557: Bottom of screen blacks out at high
 resolution w/MGA G200
Message-ID: <040.615218a2444f253c27c13706b33c4524@haiku-os.org>

#3557: Bottom of screen blacks out at high resolution w/MGA G200
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  BeOSR                    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                      |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/Graphics/Matrox  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 When setting the Screen pref to 1280x1024x32bpp or higher, the bottom 35%
 of the screen becomes black. The pointer is drawn in that zone, but
 windows etc are not. This does not happen in 1280x1024x16bpp, or
 1182x864x32bbp.

 Gfx card is MGA Millennium G200 8Mb AGP, and 1280x1024x32bpp works fine in
 R5, Dano & Zeta.

 Using Geforce TNT 16Mb AGP does not generate this behaviour.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 17:53:39 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (BeOSR)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 16:53:39 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3560: Have window status line indicate used
	disk space
Message-ID: <040.1c676ed1a7455b3941ab824cfe4859e6@haiku-os.org>

#3560: Have window status line indicate used disk space
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  BeOSR           |       Owner:  stippi        
     Type:  enhancement     |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal          |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  User Interface  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                  |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                  |  
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 The bottom window status line could be extended to show the space the
 objects in the active window use on the disk next to their number. Make
 this a user setting via Tracker prefs. Of course symlinks would be
 excluded, as they are not part of the active window. Actually, as their
 object size is zero, it probably does not even matter.

 Extended statusline example:
 14 items | 3,06 Mb

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3560>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 18:34:07 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (js)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 17:34:07 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3561: Objective C not supported by gcc
Message-ID: <037.4af84252cdb1d45fb29f07d305277aed@haiku-os.org>

#3561: Objective C not supported by gcc
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  js            |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Hi!

 The gcc that comes with Haiku does not support Objective C. This is not a
 big problem atm, as there aren't many (any?) Objective C apps for Haiku
 yet, but it won't hurt to enable it. All you need to do is change the
 configure line of gcc and add objc to --enable-languages there (currently
 you have --enable-languages=c,c++, you could change it to either --enable-
 languages=c,c++,objc,obj-c++ or --enable-languages=c,c++,objc. Including
 obj-c++ would be better so that bindings for Haiku's C++ APIs could be
 written). Reason is that I like Haiku and I'd like to port my Objective C
 Framework Library to it so that applications using it run out of the box
 on Haiku.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3561>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 19:28:37 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (anevilyak)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 18:28:37 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3563: Odd firefox problem on hybrid build
Message-ID: <044.4238e54eef7729ac9dd9da2e27fb5aad@haiku-os.org>

#3563: Odd firefox problem on hybrid build
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  anevilyak              |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  bug                    |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/runtime_loader  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 I have a gcc4 firefox. If I try to run this on gcc2 haiku w/ hybrid libs,
 on first start it exits (you get control back at the shell), and then its
 last thread sits at 100% CPU usage. If you attempt to attach gdb to it, it
 immediately exits (you see the child exit in gdb right after attaching).
 On subsequent runs this doesn't occur. It also doesn't occur when running
 the same exact binaries on gcc4 haiku. Dropping into the kernel debugger
 and looking at the offending thread yields the following:

 {{{
 kdebug> teams
 team           id  parent      name
 0x8128bcc0    279  0x8119e198  firefox-bin
 0x8119ee58    217  0x81269b28  Terminal

New description:

 I have a gcc4 firefox. If I try to run this on gcc2 haiku w/ hybrid libs,
 on first start it exits (you get control back at the shell), and then its
 last thread sits at 100% CPU usage. If you attempt to attach gdb to it, it
 immediately exits (you see the child exit in gdb right after attaching).
 On subsequent runs this doesn't occur, firefox simply starts up and runs
 normally. It also doesn't occur when running the same exact binaries on
 gcc4 haiku. Dropping into the kernel debugger and looking at the offending
 thread yields the following:

 {{{

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 20:17:26 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Adek336)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 19:17:26 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3564: Heavy non-interactive processes get
	Display Priority
Message-ID: <042.bc831fe556eeb32ee28a10cf9d43daaf@haiku-os.org>

#3564: Heavy non-interactive processes get Display Priority
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal     |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  - General  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:             |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:             |  
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 When running "make" in some app's sources dir, you can see in Deskbar that
 make and it's children's threads get Display Priority. It makes the system
 unresponsive, this is particularly intense under VmWare. Tested with
 r29472. This probably is not a problem with Terminal nor bash. Changing
 priorities of the mentioned threads helps for a while (until new instances
 of gcc et al. get spawned)

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3564>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Comment(by humdinger):

 Generally, I like the idea, though I see Rene's problem with it.

 How about keeping just the number of items without filesizes and only
 update the items and their size when a selection is made. If you only
 select a few files, the updated info is instantaneous, if you include
 folders it unavoidably takes some time. As long as the system stays
 responsive and shows what it's doing by counting up the filesize, that's
 OK IMO.

#3178: [Firefox] After installing Haiku to partition, Firefox at first run doesn't
open a window
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal     |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  - General  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:             |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:  3563       |  
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------

Comment(by bonefish):

 Just as in #3563 the KDL stack trace shows the thread entering an
 acquire_sem() syscall. My guess would be that it's an infinite loop in the
 Firefox code, trying to acquire an invalid semaphore.

 Why attaching a debugger would terminate the team I have no idea. Might be
 a bug in the debug support code. Enabling debug output in
 src/system/kernel/debug/user_debugger might yield some helpful
 information.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 20:50:50 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (bonefish)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 19:50:50 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3556: KPartition keeps disk system module
	loaded
In-Reply-To: <040.cf75cfc8e217230d796dca23df684301@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.cf75cfc8e217230d796dca23df684301@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.6653e83691001a6dad75a0c841d89790@haiku-os.org>

#3556: KPartition keeps disk system module loaded
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  axeld          |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by bonefish):

 That's not a bug, but a feature. Not keeping the disk systems loaded would
 mean that for every partition operation you'd have to load and unload the
 respective disk system.

 Replacing disk systems is intended to work based on node monitoring. All
 partitions associated with the disk system in question would need to be
 invalidated and rescanned. Care must be taken regarding mounted and busy
 partitions.

 Whoever added node monitoring to the DDM apparently forgot to add that
 feature. :-)

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3556#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 21:13:07 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (bonefish)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 20:13:07 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3564: Heavy non-interactive processes get
 Display Priority
In-Reply-To: <042.bc831fe556eeb32ee28a10cf9d43daaf@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.bc831fe556eeb32ee28a10cf9d43daaf@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.fbd60a87e04d3917ef08e479077a6f27@haiku-os.org>

#3564: Heavy non-interactive processes get Display Priority
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336                |       Owner:  jackburton    
     Type:  bug                    |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Terminal  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
Changes (by bonefish):

  * owner:  axeld => jackburton
  * component:  - General => Applications/Terminal


Comment:

 That's definitely a Terminal problem. The main thread of a fork()ed
 processes inherits the thread priority of the fork()ing thread. The first
 shell in the Terminal is fork()ed from the application main thread, thus
 getting normal priority, but new tabs (and their associated shells) are
 created in the window thread, which has display priority. We don't set the
 child process' priority after fork()ing, which we probably should do.

 We might also want to rethink whether inheriting the thread priority on
 fork() is a good idea, but it seems the logical thing to do.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3564#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 21:30:14 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (BeOSR)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 20:30:14 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3560: Have window status line indicate
	used disk space
In-Reply-To: <040.1c676ed1a7455b3941ab824cfe4859e6@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.1c676ed1a7455b3941ab824cfe4859e6@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.d465991806ac1d9617ebe89075f2b449@haiku-os.org>

#3560: Have window status line indicate used disk space
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  BeOSR           |       Owner:  stippi        
     Type:  enhancement     |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal          |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  User Interface  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                  |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                  |  
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------

Comment(by BeOSR):

 The indicated size would be limited to the *active window only*, and not
 traverse (sub)directories.
 If you open a window, the size of any folder indicated as "-", just as it
 is for symlinks. These would be counted at that value, so zero. Only
 actual files or objects would be totaled.

 This is not really relevant for system folders, but is very handy for user
 folders.

 For an overview of used disk space per folder, DiskUsage works very well.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3560#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Comment(by luroh):

 Hang on, I think I know what is going on here; Haiku picks up the presence
 of an old deleted Haiku partition on my SATA drive (an old revision number
 in About gave it away!):[[BR]][[BR]]
 1. Booting starts from the USB stick.[[BR]]
 2. At some point during boot, the system detects an old deleted Haiku
 partition on the SATA drive and decides to set it as /boot. This explains
 why the system loaded slowly during bootsplash but fast once it reached
 Desktop.[[BR]]

 To avoid 2 from happening, I not only had to delete the old Haiku
 partition on the SATA drive, but reformat the partition with an alien file
 system to completely rid it from its BFS-edness.[[BR]][[BR]]
 Perhaps we should close this ticket as invalid and start fresh, as it
 seems to have morphed into something completely different than it
 initially was.[[BR]][[BR]]
 Tested with rev 29529.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3532#comment:6>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 14 23:46:25 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (jonas.kirilla)
Date: Sat, 14 Mar 2009 22:46:25 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3535: Scheduling stops on extra cores
In-Reply-To: <048.564440f98fc71160509051e21eb8ec02@haiku-os.org>
References: <048.564440f98fc71160509051e21eb8ec02@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <057.63acf0087b8e5a28986f33d0788ae7e3@haiku-os.org>

#3535: Scheduling stops on extra cores
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  jonas.kirilla  |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by jonas.kirilla):

 It happens also on r29503, gcc2.

 Step 3 is likely redundant.

 A while after having started 4 cat threads, Pulse shows one core at 100%
 activity and 3 idle cores. KDL output looks to me as if all four cat
 processes are alive and running each on its own core. The only difference
 I can see, post vs pre, is that some flags and fault handlers differ.
 (Maybe these differ between when a process runs in the kernel and when in
 runs in userland?)

 The cat processes can be stopped by ctr-c, which appears to release the
 "idle" cores, from Pulse?s point of view. Whether they are truly idle I
 can?t say.

 Pulse and ProcessController sometimes display differently. Post-issue and
 post-killing the cat threads, ProcessController may show some cores pinned
 at 100% even when there is clearly no load anymore.

 (I don?t know if this is related at all, but I just tried opening all
 preferences while having all four cores loaded, resulting in multiple
 errors of this kind: "Could not open X with application X (Unknown
 Application Error (-2147418110)".)

 Having 4 cat processes and Pulse showing 1 core loaded and 3 cores "idle",
 turning off the loaded core makes Haiku freeze, but F12 can still be
 pressed. In KDL, "running" shows 3 cat processes running on the supposedly
 idle cores and an idle thread running on the previously loaded, now turned
 off, first core.

 See KDL output.

--

From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Sun, 15 Mar 2009 17:16:05 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3565: Putting Expander into Deskbar's
	"Applications"
Message-ID: <044.29007419a069533dcdf6016a335e189e@haiku-os.org>

#3565: Putting Expander into Deskbar's "Applications"
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger              |       Owner:  korli         
     Type:  enhancement            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Expander  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Checking the options "Automatically expand files" and "Close window when
 done expanding" leaves the app not easily available to the inexperienced
 user to revert these settings or any options from the preferences panel.

 He has probably always just double-clicked an archive to start Expander.
 Now it will always expand automatically and quit when done.

 The solution is of course to start Expander without an archive. Easy: just
 start it from /boot/beos/apps/Expander or enter "Expander" in Terminal.
 Joe User maybe doesn't know that, however...

 So, back into Deskbar's "Applications" menu?

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Mar 15 19:03:21 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Adek336)
Date: Sun, 15 Mar 2009 18:03:21 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3566: Data corruption when compiling under
	hybrid
Message-ID: <042.e061678fdf344c6417af6a462797356c@haiku-os.org>

#3566: Data corruption when compiling under hybrid
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal     |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  - General  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:             |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:             |  
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 I've been compiling some userland applications a lot recently. I have seen

 under vmware, hybrid, two BFS partitions, code is being compiled on the
 non-boot partition, suddenly the build process ends with an error like
 garbage in config.status, syntax error in .c file, lack of separator in
 Makefile. These error always turned out to be caused by corruption in the
 mentioned files. This happened a lot in a revision circa r29330, now under
 circa r29500 I didn't see it but perhaps it's just a matter of chance.
 Perhaps related to #3347 which happened even more often than data
 corruption.

 under real hw, r29503, hybrid, two partitions, compiling on non-boot
 partition, I've seen this happen once: compiling compiling then boom
 restart, after booting up many files are corrupt, even sources which were
 compiled an hour earlier didn't want to compile again due to garbage in
 files, some stuff in /boot/common/bin and /boot/common/lib didn't work
 because of elf header errors like if they were corrupted.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Mar 15 21:29:54 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (BeOSR)
Date: Sun, 15 Mar 2009 20:29:54 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3560: Have window status line indicate
	used disk space
In-Reply-To: <040.1c676ed1a7455b3941ab824cfe4859e6@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.1c676ed1a7455b3941ab824cfe4859e6@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.0737985a718e549e9f8a01ab4b91b656@haiku-os.org>

#3560: Have window status line indicate used disk space
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  BeOSR           |       Owner:  stippi        
     Type:  enhancement     |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal          |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  User Interface  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                  |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                  |  
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------

Comment(by BeOSR):

 To be semantically correct, the status line would show the number of
 *files*, not *items*, and their cumulated disk space. As folders and
 symlinks aren't really files but placeholders, this should be clear.

 Humdinger's point of showing the number of selected files and their total
 size is absolutely correct, so there'd be 2 views:[[BR]]

 Basic view, nothing selected:[[BR]]
 15 files | 5.4 Mb[[BR]]

 With some files selected:[[BR]]
 6 files selected | 1.2 Mb

 Finally, it would be handy to have some indicator in the status line that
 parent folders can be browsed from that point, a lot of people don't know
 about this. Maybe use two dots to indicate parent directory or a dot and
 an up arrow or something? The very long horizontal scrollbar is a waste of
 space in most cases anyway.[[BR]]
 ^. | 15 files | 5.4 Mb < [scrollbar] >[[BR]]
 .. | 15 files selected | 5.4 Mb < [scrollbar] >

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3560#comment:4>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Mar 15 23:40:04 2009

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #2643: Black screen when DVI connected
In-Reply-To: <043.0786930e484a2f240575b79901142eea@haiku-os.org>

#2643: Black screen when DVI connected
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  andreasf                 |       Owner:  rudolfc       
     Type:  bug                      |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/Graphics/nVidia  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------

Comment(by JeremyVisser):

 Replying to [comment:16 andreasf]:
 > Booting up with VGA and then rebooting with DVI does not work here.

 While you were booted up in VGA, did you go to Preferences ? Screens and
 choose a new video mode to use? If I didn't do that, then DVI wouldn't
 work for me either.

 If you did the above, I suspect it didn't work because you used different
 monitors, and Haiku was resetting the mode settings because it detected
 different display IDs. I have a HP L1740 monitor that has has both DVI and
 VGA inputs, so it wouldn't reset the display settings if I switch from VGA
 to DVI.

 I found that if I used a live USB copy of Haiku and switched it between a
 few computers, each computer would remember my unique preferred screen
 resolution for each screen, so that seems to confirm my suspicions.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/2643#comment:19>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3532: PANIC: ASSERT FAILED
 (src/add-ons/kernel/file_systems/bfs/BlockAllocator.cpp:448):
 !fLargestValid || start + length <= fLargestStart |
In-Reply-To: <040.96fbaa7aa542ac9994042ade17cb3abd@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.96fbaa7aa542ac9994042ade17cb3abd@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.9aa2fcd651f66ef032ad47e48745ad1d@haiku-os.org>

#3532: PANIC: ASSERT FAILED (src/add-
ons/kernel/file_systems/bfs/BlockAllocator.cpp:448): !fLargestValid ||
start + length <= fLargestStart |
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  luroh             |       Owner:  axeld         
      Type:  bug               |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  File Systems/BFS  |     Version:  R1 development
Resolution:  invalid           |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  All               |    Blocking:                
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
Changes (by axeld):

  * status:  new => closed
  * resolution:  => invalid


Comment:

 Okay, thanks for investigating this further! The problem is that the BIOS
 does not tell Haiku that it booted from USB. Once in the kernel, Haiku
 usually has to guess the drive from which it had been booted before; it
 uses some kind of heuristics, but apparently, they could be improved as
 your case shows.

 But I agree, we should open a new ticket for this problem. Should I do it,
 or do you want to? :-)

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3532#comment:7>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  bga          |       Owner:  mmlr          
     Type:  bug          |      Status:  assigned      
 Priority:  blocker      |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/USB  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:               |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:               |  
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------

Comment(by bga):

 Just some update to this that I noticed. I have USB ports on the back of
 my computer (4) and in its front panel (another 4). I would take they are
 connected in two different physical USB controllers.

 If I connect anything to the back ports, I have no problems (I have a
 webcam connect6ed to those and it is recognized by Haiku, although it does
 not work as UVC just started being implemented). But anything I connect to
 the ports in the front panel results in the IRQ flood (if it is plugged
 during boot, the boot process hangs, if plugged in when the system is
 running, it locks up).

 Based on this I would guess the problem could be due to IRQ sharing
 between the problematic controller and some other hardware? If so, your
 (mmlr's) recent changes to tryu to work things like this around didn't
 work, unfortunately.

 Storage card reader I have actually works up to a point even when
 connected to the front ports. What does not work for sure and results in
 IRQ flood:

 1 - Bluetooth USB dongle.
 2 - My printer.

 So, what could cause the IRQ floos on some devices and lot on others?

 -Bruno

-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  bga          |       Owner:  mmlr          
     Type:  bug          |      Status:  assigned      
 Priority:  blocker      |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/USB  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:               |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:               |  
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------

Comment(by bga):

 Just as an addendum, I have been getting this quite frequently. I don't
 know how it happens but usually I notice it when doing "svn up" on the
 Haiku tree, Usually directories inside the .svn dirs are the ones affected
 so I am inclined to think this is happening because bad data is being
 written to the directory entry when these files are updated. It *COULD* be
 related to advisory file locking as the files are locked by svn when they
 are being updated, In fact, the first indication that the problem occured
 is that when doing svn up I get a message that i need to run svn cleanup
 (which usually fails and checking syslog shows the "Bad data" message).

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Mar 16 18:48:43 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (luroh)
Date: Mon, 16 Mar 2009 17:48:43 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3569: Haiku assumes wrong boot drive when
	booting from USB
Message-ID: <040.ead72ac5b992de82858efb2999352377@haiku-os.org>

#3569: Haiku assumes wrong boot drive when booting from USB
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  luroh          |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 (spinoff from #3532)[[BR]]
 When booting from a USB stick, Haiku picks up the presence of an old
 deleted Haiku partition on my SATA drive and sets it as /boot.

 1. Booting starts from a USB stick.[[BR]]
 2. At some point during boot, the system detects an old deleted Haiku
 partition on the SATA drive and decides to set it as /boot. This explains
 why the system loads slowly during bootsplash but fast once it reaches
 Desktop.[[BR]]
 3. Fully booted, the USB stick is now /Haiku1.

 To avoid 2 from happening, I not only have to delete the old Haiku
 partition on the SATA drive, but reformat the partition with an alien file
 system to completely rid it from its BFS-edness.

 ''axeld in #3532:[[BR]]
 The problem is that the BIOS does not tell Haiku that it booted from USB.
 Once in the kernel, Haiku usually has to guess the drive from which it had
 been booted before; it uses some kind of heuristics, but apparently, they
 could be improved as your case shows.''

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3569>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Mar 16 20:42:53 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Adek336)
Date: Mon, 16 Mar 2009 19:42:53 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3570: Volume Control in Deskbar: can't avoid
 undesired volume change
Message-ID: <042.5906ab8c8ed850cac08738c7bed8af9f@haiku-os.org>

#3570: Volume Control in Deskbar: can't avoid undesired volume change
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336            |       Owner:  anevilyak     
     Type:  enhancement        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Preferences/Media  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Check "Show Volume Control on Deskbar" in the media preflet. Now you may
 want to setup low volume with the volume control. After some time you may
 want to adjust the volume further. So you click on the volume control icon
 and the slider appears. While you're changing volume, you have the mouse
 button down, as releasing the mouse key would close the volume control.
 The mouse pointer is still where you clicked on the icon; so it's just a
 bit above the middle of the slider. On the other hand, the current volume
 slider position is far to the left.

 Experienced behaviour: The instant you move the mouse, volume control sets
 the slider to the place where the mouse pointer is - so to the middle of
 the scale. For a split second before you relower the volume, it's loud.

 Expected behaviour: after clicking the Volume Control icon on Deskbar, the
 mouse pointer is moved to the place on the slider which represents current
 volume.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3570>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

#3570: Volume Control in Deskbar: can't avoid undesired volume change
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336            |       Owner:  anevilyak     
     Type:  enhancement        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Preferences/Media  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------

Comment(by stippi):

 This will prove to be difficult. With tablets, you cannot position the
 mouse, since it will just snap back to the absolute pen position. I think
 the better approach will be to keep the slider open after the first click,
 close it if the second click goes anywhere outside the slider, otherwise
 start adopting the slider position after the second click.

--

In-Reply-To: <041.a0598fe0deafbda990f417a25f872e72@haiku-os.org>

#3424: Configure : conditionally output HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS = 1
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia        |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by mmadia):

 This script shows one method for adding HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS = 1
 to HAIKU_OUTPUT_DIR/UserBuildConfig.

 I've yet to attempt integrating this into the build system.

 {{{
 #!/bin/sh
 # THESE VARIABLES exist for testing purposes.
 HAIKU_OUTPUT_DIR='.'
 infile="$HAIKU_OUTPUT_DIR/UserBuildConfig"
 outfile="$HAIKU_OUTPUT_DIR/TempBuildConfig"

 # check if HAIKU_OUTPUT_DIR/UserBuildConfig exists
 # If yes, delete any lines containing HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS
 if [ -f "$infile" ] ; then
   grep -Ev HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS "$infile" > "$outfile"
   mv -f "$outfile" "$infile"
 fi
 # Add line to HAIKU_OUTPUT_DIR/UserBuildConfig
 echo "HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS = 1 " >> "$infile"
 }}}

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3424#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From: trac at haiku-os.org (anevilyak)
Date: Wed, 18 Mar 2009 04:52:25 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3576: runtime_loader : display which file
 triggered R5 compatibility mode in syslog
In-Reply-To: <041.69c3c79d697fd2fb7616d9bf0d038d02@haiku-os.org>
References: <041.69c3c79d697fd2fb7616d9bf0d038d02@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <050.d60935b5d9dc6fe746bd5bf980c494f2@haiku-os.org>

#3576: runtime_loader : display which file triggered R5 compatibility mode in
syslog
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia                 |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/runtime_loader  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------

Comment(by anevilyak):

 The problem is it's not the runtime loader that makes that determination.
 libnetwork.so does that directly by looking at what soname it was loaded
 as, and as such has no actual knowledge of which part of the linker chain
 was the culprit. This might be doable in the runtime loader but at least
 right now it plays no part in the compat mechanism.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3576#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------

Comment(by mmadia):

 just to note for clarity,  R5 Compatibility Mode usually occurs when
 libnetwork.so is called as libbind.so, libsocket.so, or libnet.so.

 This occurs when loading a binary or lib that was built in a version of
 BeOS.

 configure.3424-rev2.diff creates a new variable , addAlternativeGCCLibs=0

 HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS          ?= "${addAlternativeGCCLibs}" ;

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 19 01:32:58 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmadia)
Date: Thu, 19 Mar 2009 00:32:58 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #2629: Automatic disk mounting not working.
In-Reply-To: <038.a69687c7fc33e3e0b9d21ea4fc8dfaba@haiku-os.org>
References: <038.a69687c7fc33e3e0b9d21ea4fc8dfaba@haiku-os.org>

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 19 10:32:11 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (stippi)
Date: Thu, 19 Mar 2009 09:32:11 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #1444: SATA testing on real hardware -
	fails to boot
In-Reply-To: <042.6d42e64b1d90ed4f4f92d24220c524df@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.6d42e64b1d90ed4f4f92d24220c524df@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.63b33511784aa17f934e22fa4e8fe07e@haiku-os.org>

#1444: SATA testing on real hardware - fails to boot
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  scottmc       |       Owner:  marcusoverhagen
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  assigned       
 Priority:  blocker       |   Milestone:  R1             
Component:  Drivers/Disk  |     Version:  R1 development 
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  x86            
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
Changes (by stippi):

  * milestone:  R1/alpha1 => R1


Comment:

 I think that tickets about Haiku not working on specific hardware should
 not be in the R1/alpha milestone, because there are great chances of
 always finding some specific hardware that Haiku does not boot on. The
 hardware for which this ticket has been initially posted for actually
 works now. Other hardware does not. I believe that only issues which
 affect all hardware should be in R1/alpha. Like for example missing ATAPI
 support in the new ATA bus manager. But it's not clear right now if we
 really go with that driver, since work on it is currently on hold.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/1444#comment:46>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 19 10:42:21 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (stippi)
Date: Thu, 19 Mar 2009 09:42:21 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #1053: Write Support in the Intel
	Partitioning Module
In-Reply-To: <043.39f8e14bdd816d4f0d794bd49c4e7683@haiku-os.org>
References: <043.39f8e14bdd816d4f0d794bd49c4e7683@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <052.5107c218f1a1a58daa03f0913c7c3cad@haiku-os.org>

#1053: Write Support in the Intel Partitioning Module
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  bonefish       |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  enhancement    |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:  1822           |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
Changes (by stippi):

  * milestone:  R1/alpha1 => R1


Comment:

 Removing form the R1/alpha1 milestone, for the same reasons as #1822.
 Actually, write support is there for the features we need (initializing
 partitions). The most important problems are:

 1) Retrieving possible disk system candidates for completely empty
 volumes. Currently, an empty harddrive can be initialized with BFS, but
 the BDiskDevice methods to retrieve disk systems do not work, since a
 proper object hierarchy is not being setup in the kernel.

 2) Write support in the Intel Extended Partition. The Intel Partition Map
 write support could actually work already, but needs proper testing.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/1053#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 19 11:01:55 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (HAL)
Date: Thu, 19 Mar 2009 10:01:55 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3578: Application to import photos from Kodak
	C1013
Message-ID: <038.31e50338d3d439bb34aa3e7960c995b8@haiku-os.org>

#3578: Application to import photos from Kodak C1013
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  HAL          |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement  |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal       |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  - General    |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:               |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:               |  
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 This camera has an internal storage and a SD card can be plugged in. There
 is no way that the cameras internal storage or SD card can be mounted to
 copy photos by Tracker or no application that can detect the camera and
 import photos.
 I tried Exposure (available from Haikuware) but there is no plugin for
 this application for the Kodak C1013. Also the installer for this
 application does not work in Haiku. It installs in Beos5.05Bone alright.
 The only application that works well with this camera in Linux is: f-spot
 that comes with GNOME. this application lists it as a PTP type camera when
 it is plugged into a USB socket and can import photos when this is
 selected.
 So it might be possible to use the source for f-spot to make a plugin for
 Exposure.
 I looked at the developers web site for Exposure and he is no longer
 developing it. I emailed him but he hasn't replied. The developers web
 address is:
 http://www.gwsoft.co.uk/exposure/

--

 HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS = 1
In-Reply-To: <041.a0598fe0deafbda990f417a25f872e72@haiku-os.org>
References: <041.a0598fe0deafbda990f417a25f872e72@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <050.c46d5308ab290b2efccec0165d054d6f@haiku-os.org>

#3424: Configure : conditionally output HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS = 1
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  mmadia        |       Owner:  bonefish      
      Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1 development
Resolution:  fixed         |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  All           |    Blocking:                
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
Changes (by bonefish):

  * status:  new => closed
  * resolution:  => fixed


Comment:

 Replying to [comment:4 mmadia]:
 > configure.3424-rev2.diff creates a new variable ,
 addAlternativeGCCLibs=0  and sets it =1 when --alternative-gcc-output-dir
 is detected.
 >
 > This is added to ${outputDir}/build/BuildConfig:
 > HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS          ?= "${addAlternativeGCCLibs}" ;

 Applied in r29607, but adjusted a bit. Since
 HAIKU_ADD_ALTERNATIVE_GCC_LIBS is only tested for non-emptiness, setting
 it to 0 wouldn't work.

 > On a side note, is there any reason why ${alternativeGCCOutputDir} is
 not encapsulated in double quotes?

 ATM path names with spaces aren't really supported anyway, so that doesn't
 really make a difference.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3424#comment:5>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Mar 19 16:40:12 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmadia)
Date: Thu, 19 Mar 2009 15:40:12 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3580: details : "Add encoding support to our
	MediaKit"
Message-ID: <041.e3c210482c7c405b1190d499639cac75@haiku-os.org>

#3580: details : "Add encoding support to our MediaKit"
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia          |       Owner:  marcusoverhagen
     Type:  enhancement     |      Status:  new            
 Priority:  normal          |   Milestone:  R1             
Component:  Kits/Media Kit  |     Version:                 
Blockedby:                  |    Platform:  All            
 Blocking:                  |  
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 This has some additional notes regarding Haiku's Google Summer of Code(tm)
 project idea: "Add encoding support to our MediaKit"

 This project has a focus on designing and implementing the API's to allow
 encoders to communicate with MediaKit. This will allow any program that is
 aware of MediaKit to utilize any available encoders that are also aware of
 MediaKit.

 While the focus is on API design and implementation, at a minimum, an
 encoder for video and audio needs to be created to allow testing of this
 API.  Also, it is beneficial to have an understanding of the features that
 are required by the encoders to work with this API.

 There are two major aspects for API design and implementation:

 The first is implementing the pre-existing BeOS encoder API methods.  The
 methods currently exist as function stubs.  No API design is needed nor
 expected.

 The second is designing and implementing a backend for the MediaKit API.
 Since BeOS's encoder/decoder and reader/writer API was private, there is
 no API documentation to follow.  It is suggested to study Haiku's existing
 decoder implementation and use that as a guide for creating the encoder
 API.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3580>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  walera       |       Owner:  mmlr

 I have USB Composite Device (port replicator for notebook). This device
 include USB hub and connected to it:
 USB to LAN, USB to COM, USB to LPT, USB to PS/2 and USB to Audio. All
 those devices normally detected under Windows (see screenshoot in
 attachment). But by connect this device under Haiku normally detected only
 USB to LAN (device 0b95/7720) and partly work additional USB ports (see
 log from listusb). "'''Partly''' work additional USB ports" because not
 all devices detected on those ports. For example: USB Flash and USB HDD
 normally work, but USB mouse not work on those ports. BTW I try connect
 other USB hub and find identical problem: USB mouse not work ''after'' USB
 hub.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Mar 20 01:03:14 2009

#3585: endless loop in heap grower
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  axeld          |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by axeld):

 More info, I get this one when it happens - it seems it's currently always
 reproducible when the app I'm currently working on crashes:
 {{{
 KERN: thread 1147 tried to acquire kernel semaphore 0.
 }}}

 From then on, the heap grower is always trying to acquire semaphore 0
 which obviously fails every time. Maybe that semaphore is deleted from
 userland somehow, I'll have a look.

--

 installations (when I test it here, it works). It's probably best to file
 a ticket in the Bezilla bug tracker and let the Bezilla guys have a look.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Mar 20 21:00:00 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (anevilyak)
Date: Fri, 20 Mar 2009 20:00:00 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3578: Application to import photos from
	Kodak C1013
In-Reply-To: <038.31e50338d3d439bb34aa3e7960c995b8@haiku-os.org>
References: <038.31e50338d3d439bb34aa3e7960c995b8@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <047.33621b9c4a0a4df41b32fb9849cc2784@haiku-os.org>

#3578: Application to import photos from Kodak C1013
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  HAL          |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement  |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal       |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  - General    |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:               |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:               |  
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------

Comment(by anevilyak):

 That depends on how the camera exposes itself. Some cameras expose
 themselves as USB mass storage, and as such their on board SD cards wind
 up looking like an ordinary hard disk. PTP cameras do not do this however,
 so making them appear in Tracker would be significantly more involved, and
 would probably involve writing a pseudo-filesystem to make the PTP camera
 appear like a disk. This would probably be doable via libptp and
 userlandfs, but it's certainly not trivial.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3578#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Mar 20 22:13:29 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (franxico)
Date: Fri, 20 Mar 2009 21:13:29 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3587: Tracker - Icon View should auto arrange
	icons
Message-ID: <043.3e0040a1a0f72b76a8e519d7d47c1195@haiku-os.org>

#3587: Tracker - Icon View should auto arrange icons
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  franxico              |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement           |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Tracker  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                        |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                        |  
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 In Icon View (and Mini-Icon) mode, Tracker should auto arrange icons when
 the windows is resized. This way all icons could be viewed, fitting in the
 windows, instead making the user to scroll or to move them manually.

 In r29618 (as in BeOS R5), icons are always still. Doing a Clean Up
 (Alt+K) won't help in this case. Only doing Alt+Shift+K would do it, but
 this feature is hiddem (thanks [http://betips.net/1997/09/09/clean-up-
 your-icons/ Betips]!). In fact, if auto arrange is implemented, we could
 eliminate Clean Up and its variations.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3587>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Mar 21 15:02:48 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Adek336)
Date: Sat, 21 Mar 2009 14:02:48 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3591: poll(NULL, 0, t)
Message-ID: <042.6ad2d28ddd9d2ccab6c3556f1661183d@haiku-os.org>

#3591: poll(NULL, 0, t)
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336        |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 {{{
 #include <poll.h>
 #include <stdio.h>

 int main()
 {
        int i = poll(NULL, 0, 2000);
        fprintf(stderr, "%d\n", i);
        return 0;
 }
 }}}

 Haiku: immiedately prints -1
 Linux, FreeBSD: sleeps for 2 seconds and prints 0

 This program passes fds = NULL but at the same time, nfds = 0; so
 there isn't any actual null pointer dereference. The docs
 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/007908799/xsh/poll.html don't seem to
 cover this issue. I guess Haiku should follow the standard undocumented
 behaviour.


 http://www.freelists.org/post/haiku-development/poll2-with-nfds0

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3591>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Reporter:  BeOSR                    |       Owner:  rudolfc

 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/Graphics/Matrox  |     Version:  R1 development
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------

Comment(by anevilyak):

 Indeed, 1280x1024 at 32pp equates to approximately a 5MB frame buffer, ergo
 doubling that would most definitely not fit into the 8MB of graphics RAM
 total that the card had. Though we should probably be smarter about
 handling that case by the sounds of it.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Mar 22 17:59:33 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Haiku)
Date: Sun, 22 Mar 2009 16:59:33 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3593: strtod doesn't support "INF" input
Message-ID: <042.cc826bf976486fa02ed203176ab878b2@haiku-os.org>

#3593: strtod doesn't support "INF" input
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336            |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/libroot.so  |     Version:  R1 development
 Keywords:                     |   Blockedby:                
 Platform:  All                |    Blocking:                
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 {{{

 #include <stdio.h>
 #include <stdlib.h>

 int main()
 {
         char * endptr;
         double d = strtod("inf", &endptr);
         fprintf(stderr, "%f '%s'\n", d, endptr);
         return 0;
 }

 }}}

 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/000095399/functions/strtod.html:[[br]]
 {{{
 The expected form of the subject sequence is an optional plus or minus
 sign, then one of the following:

 [...]

 * One of INF or INFINITY, ignoring case
 * One of NAN or NAN(n-char-sequenceopt), ignoring case in the NAN part,
 where:[...]
 }}}

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3593>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Comment(by Adek336):

 The link is
 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/000095399/functions/strtod.html
